name: The Dark Musketeer: a drow roleplay build
author: francois.demers.4

posts.author: francois.demers.4
posts.content:
Have you read the Three Musketeers? If so, you might have heard there was a fourth one with them. I present you the DARK MUSKETEER!

Warning: Thisbuildisforrolepaypurposemainlythereforenotaseriouspvporpvmbuild. Theauthorofthisbuildisnotresponsibleofanystrugglethereadermayhavewhileplayingwiththisbuild.

Wait, the fourth one was named d'Artagnan? And he was not a drow? Nevermind that, you still get the build anyway.

Race: Human
Alignment: TN
Class: Druid 6, Fighter 27, Shifter 7

STR: 8
DEX: 10
CON: 18 (34)
INT: 14
WIS: 14
CHA: 8

Unshifted/Drow
HP: 775/805
BAB:  26/37
AC: 12/25
For: 37/37
Ref: 18/23
Wil: 20/20

Con: 43
Dis: 43
Hea: 43
Lis: 15
Spe: 40
Spo: 15
Tum: 20

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Alright, someone has to ask: why so enormous an investment in Constitution and Epic Toughness? I'm not knocking it, just asking.

Cheers

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
That's because Epic Drow form overrides your natural strength & dexterity but not the constitution.
So, he made a fat D'artagnan that will also become nimble & strong, haha.

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
I'm confused by a few things.  First is your Level Description shows 23 Barbarian levels and 11 shifter, but in the Level Guide you have Fighter levels and 7 shifter.

But what most confounds me is why not go for Epic Drow form?  What's the point of all Con investment if not going for the Epic Drow (better AB, +6 weapon, more SR, Improved Evasion, higher AC, higher Str and Dex)? After all, you do tout it as a Drow build.
To effect that, you would need a split something like Druid7/Shifter17/Fighter16.  Likewise, you could replace Fighter with CoT for enormous save boost, or with Blackguard and pump Charisma instead of Constitution.  

But it's nice to see folks having fun with this stuff still.  Cheers!

posts.author: francois.demers.4
posts.content: Whoops! I have copy-pasted from another build I made and I forgot to change that part. The reason why I did not bother to get the epic shape was because I would get two shifter feats forcing me to get either great wisdom or epic energy resistance, and I would lose around five fighter feats. Also, thanks for those multiclass ideas. I might change this build someday.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
I agree with grizzled_dwarflord on switching to a Dru7/Shif17/Figh16 (or Dru7/Shif19/Figh14). Losing 5 feats for a build with this many Figh levels isn't really an issue. Swapping Epic Toughness 5 for Epic Drow Warrior, Undead Shape, and an EER feat is an easy choice, especially since you can add Toughness to partially make up for it.
Even if you do stick with this build you should change the class spread to Dru7/Shif7/Figh26. Figh27 doesn't add anything to this build, and in exchange you get access to level 4 Druid spells.

Race choice and ability spread are both perfect, there isn't anything that can be done to improve them.

Personally I would drop Called Shot, since you already get Improved Disarm and Improved Knockdown.
I would also drop Expertise and Improved Expertise since your AC will be terrible anyway, although if you play in an environment where AC item properties merge properly then they might be worth keeping.
I'm not sure if Extend Spell is worth taking for this build since you don't have enough slots to really take advantage of it. Most of your buffs will be hours or turns per level, with extended Blood Frenzy only lasting for 14 rounds even with 7 Druid levels.
Unless Perfect Health has been modified in the environment you'll use this build in you should drop it. The only way you'll fail a disease or poison check is if you roll a 1, and even if that happens you can simply remove it yourself with Druid spells.
Swap Great Fortitude for Epic Fortitude, if you want Great Fortitude as well then swap it with a pre-epic feat.
If you plan to stick with this build then you should also shuffle your feats to replace Epic Toughness 5 with Great CON 4 and Toughness for better HP, saves, and skills.
Taking Epic Toughness is usually a sign of either a poorly optimised build or a build with too many feats.

I suggest you move the points in Listen and Spot elsewhere, at higher levels there's no real difference between 15 Listen/Spot and 0 Listen/Spot.
Consider putting 1 point into Disable Trap and Open Lock so that you can at least attempt to use them.
If you take your final Dru level at 40 then you can get 45 Spellcraft (43 ranks, 2 INT) for an extra +1 saves vs spells at the cost of 1 Discipline.
Also consider streamlining the skill progression instead of using Tumble dumps, since the extra Tumble at lower levels will help with avoiding AoOs. Once you have 14 modified Tumble then you can switch back to Tumble dumps, although it might be best to keep it streamlined in case of Curse Song or other skill decreasing effects.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Yunim, went totally objective in his post, haha.

Yeah, Francois build has many (& I mean, many!) points where it could be improved upon, but I have some sympathy wherever someone makes an RP-build & he's new to this wonderful guild as well. The only (major) foul that I saw afterward, was that he didn't go for the Epic Drow shape when it kinda is the whole point of this build, fewer feats or not. Besides, at epic levels, the lesser Drow shape probably won't cut it at all. He should also try to make his posts a little more readable too.

Anyway, I wanted to mention here one of the major reasons why most "shape-shifter" builds are not more well-known & why not many people play them, Dragon-shape excluded, of course.  The Dark Musketeer's AB is 34. Not 44, but 34. Let that sink in for a while. Yes, back in the day many people, myself included have played such characters & I have no problem playing them again, but they are not exactly hot material, so to speak. You can optimize the build further, with Epic Drow-shape & reach an AB of 37 & with the +6 longsword that's included with that form, have an AB of 43 (49 w/maxed-out strength). It then becomes playable in my opinion. Epic kobold commando gets +2 AB over that along with HiPS & 5d6 sneak-attack as well, plus it looks very funny, making it the go-to humanoid shape for such things, no wonder Mick made such a build a while ago

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi francois. I don't pretend to know about Druids or Shifters, so this is about something else that Valerfor raised in an earlier post.

It would be really helpful if you could follow the format detailed here when posting builds. You're most of the way there, but things like a separate skills schedule and fewer abbreviations (particularly when they are used for two different things, like Con for both Constitution and Concentration) make the build much easier to follow.

I'd hate to have to shift these idiosyncratic builds of yours to the Unfinalized Builds forum, after all!

Cheers

posts.author: francois.demers.4
posts.content:
I have rearranged the build accordingly to the format. Thank you, Stagmeister.

On an additionnal note, I would like your opinion on the two following things:
1. I am planning to make a kobolt build similar do Mick Dagger's Yip one but was planning to reach the epic shape instead of the standard shape. Though, this would make the death attack weaker and easier to resist the paralysis effect. Should I still multiclass to assassin or should I multiclass to blackguard instead for more survivability?
2. I am also planning a more serious build like a Fighter/Weapon Master build with some spellcasting abilities but I am not decided between Wizard and Bard. Bard has UMD, Tumble and Spellcraft compared to Wizard having only spellcraft but Wizard has very good buff spells that can be reached at lower level compared to Bard and would not force me to put points in Charisma to be able to use the spells.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks a lot, francois, it's appreciated.

As far as your thoughts for other builds go, I'm afraid you're asking the wrong man. I'm in the midst of building my first caster - a Sorcerer, as it happens, which is of no use to you - and I've never played, let alone built, a Druid or Shifter. I'd pop your thoughts into a build request and let those of the Guild who know what they're talking about offer their advice.

As far as a Fighter/ WM/ Bard or Wiz is concerned, it will really depend on what you want to focus on. Just getting to WM takes 6 feats, only leaving you 2 pre-epic (assuming you go human, otherwise 1) ones, and you'll most likely be wanting Blind Fight and at least one of the Knockdowns, as well as Imp Crit and Weapon Finesse if you're going for a Dex build. Of course, you can take some of these as Fighter bonus feats, but the more Fighter you take, the less room you'll have for the other classes - and if you're investing so many feats into just getting WM, a few piddling levels seems something of a waste. If you want Bard or Wiz merely for buffing purposes, I'd be tempted to forget the spells and use Bard Song - maybe something like a Fighter 8/ WM 22/ Bard 10? Again, though, I'd put something up on the build requests forum: you're likely to get better suggestions that way.

Cheers

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
francois.demers.4 wrote: ↑
Jan 03, 2021
I have rearranged the build accordingly to the format. Thank you, Stagmeister.

On an additionnal note, I would like your opinion on the two following things:
1. I am planning to make a kobolt build similar do Mick Dagger's Yip one but was planning to reach the epic shape instead of the standard shape. Though, this would make the death attack weaker and easier to resist the paralysis effect. Should I still multiclass to assassin or should I multiclass to blackguard instead for more survivability?
2. I am also planning a more serious build like a Fighter/Weapon Master build with some spellcasting abilities but I am not decided between Wizard and Bard. Bard has UMD, Tumble and Spellcraft compared to Wizard having only spellcraft but Wizard has very good buff spells that can be reached at lower level compared to Bard and would not force me to put points in Charisma to be able to use the spells
@Mick Dagger @webshaman1 number one is for you guys!

2- There are plenty of options for spellswords, but they typically don't stop halfway through on the casting class. WM / Fighter would already take up a lot of the build and end up probably being too much trouble for the benefit they would grant if you decide to add a 3rd class. But if you must, I'd suggest Wizard or Bard 23 / WM 7 / Fighter 10 as the least bad split for the classes.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
My Yip Squeak went Druid 5/Shifter 17/Assassin 13

With Dev Crit on his Shortsword of "I will totally wreck you", he is pretty good.

There is an enormous valley pre-epic, that makes one howl and gnash teeth - it is NOT pretty.  Took me ages to climb out of that valley, but after that, the build performs marvelously - totally different.  In epic levels, Yip Squeak performed admirably well and was a lot of fun to play.

Note that I levelled Yip Squeak on WoG.  YMMV

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
One thing to keep in mind is that if one goes BG instead of Ass, then one forgoes UMD.

And UMD really lets the build shine, imo.
